item.title: Conditionals
item.description:
1min 43sec read

I decided to write about conditional sentences. It should help me to memorize how to properly build the conditional sentences. Conditional sentence is built from ‚Äúif‚Äù (condition) and ‚Äúmain‚Äù (result) clauses. There are three main types of conditional sentences.

Zero Conditional

Zero Conditional is used when we talk about general facts. Both parts of the conditional clause use ‚ÄúPresent Simple‚Äù time.

If you finish the university, you become smarter.
If you study math, your logic skills become better.
You get a present if you write to Santa.

One Conditional

  1. The first type of First Conditional is used when we talk about possible events that may possibly happen. ‚Äúif‚Äù clause uses ‚ÄúPresent Simple‚Äù time, and ‚Äúmain‚Äù clause uses ‚ÄúFuture Indefinite‚Äù time.

If I have enough time, I will study math.
If I have a working visa, I will start to work in Germany.
I will walk around the lake if I write a post in my blog.

¬† ¬† b. The second type of First Conditional is used when we talk about events that unlikely happen. ‚Äúif‚Äù clause uses ‚Äúshould + infinitive‚Äù and ‚Äúmain‚Äù clause uses ‚ÄúFuture Indefinite‚Äù time.

If I should have enough time, I will study category theory.
If I shouldn‚Äôt have a working visa, I will finish the ‚ÄúHow to prove it‚Äù book till July.
I will start to work on ‚ÄúVerified Functional Programming in Agda‚Äù if I should finish the ‚ÄúHow to prove it‚Äù book.

Two Conditional

Second Conditional is used when we talk about an unreal event in the present time. ‚Äúif‚Äù clause uses ‚ÄúPast Simple‚Äù time and ‚Äúmain‚Äù clause uses ‚Äúwould + infinitive‚Äù.

If I had enough time, I would study Japanese.
If I could surf, I would fly to Australia.
I would become rich if I won a lottery.

Three Conditional

Third Conditional is used when we talk about an absolutely unreal event in the past. ‚Äúif‚Äù clause uses ‚ÄúPast Perfect Subjunctive‚Äù and ‚Äúmain‚Äù clause uses ‚Äúwould + Perfect infinitive‚Äù.

If I had had enough time, I would have studied math last year.
If I had written a post in my blog, I would have walked around the lake yesterday.
I would have bought the island in the Pacific Ocean last year if I had won the national lottery.

Mixed Conditionals

  1. ‚Äúif‚Äù clause is in the past and ‚Äúmain‚Äù clause is in the present or future.

If you had run a marathon last year, you would feel better now.
If I had written a post in my blog, I would walk around the lake now.
I would be rich now if I had won a lottery yesterday.

¬† ¬† b. ‚Äúif‚Äù clause doesn‚Äôt have a specific time and ‚Äúmain‚Äù clause is in the past.

If she wasn‚Äôt so smart, she would not have passed her exam.
If I wasn‚Äôt so brave, I wouldn‚Äôt have jumped with a parachute.
She would have passed her exam if she wasn‚Äôt so stupid.

Weekly goals analysis

I want to start from the goals for the week. I have set them in the previous week.

However, now I know that the amount of something shouldn‚Äôt be the main factor of estimation. Since exercises may have a different level of difficulty, and that‚Äôs the case for this week.

Every person with an aim to be successful should devote part of the life to the sport. Walking on 40 kilometers per week is hard to call a sport, as maximum, a physical activity. Error reporting should be UX friendly and very simple, simpler than using regular comments otherwise, this whole idea becomes useless. My main priority on the technical side is ‚ÄúHow to prove it‚Äù book for now.

item.title: Haskell eXchange 2016
item.description:
3min 57sec read

A few weeks ago I was able to attend the ‚ÄúHaskell eXchange‚Äù conference in London. In this post, I‚Äôd like to introduce readers to functional programming and briefly highlight the advantages and techniques of functional programming which I learned from a talk1 by Don Stewart, the author of the book ‚ÄúReal World Haskell‚Äù. Then I‚Äôll share some thoughts about how companies might start to integrate functional programming into their tech stack.

Introduction to functional programming

What is functional programming?
A style of building programs using mathematical functions.

What is mathematical function?
A relation exists between a set of inputs and a set of outputs; each with the property that each input is related to exactly one output.

Let me give an example:

var x = 1;

function impure(y) {
  x = x + y;
  return x;
}
  
function pure(x) {
  return x + 1;
}

console.log(impure(3)); // 4
console.log(impure(3)); // 7

console.log(pure(3)); // 4
console.log(pure(3)); // 4

Impure functions return different result for the same input (number 3). In other words ‚àí impure functions have side-effects.

Why is this bad?
Because you lose modularity and it is harder to think about functions with side-effects.

On the other hand, it‚Äôs really easy to compose pure functions:

function compose(f,g) {
   return function(x) {
     return f(g(x));
   }
}

function plusOne(x) {
  return x + 1;
}

var plusTwo = compose(plusOne, plusOne);
var plusThree = compose(plusTwo, plusOne);

console.log(plusOne(1)); // 2
console.log(plusTwo(1)); // 3
console.log(plusThree(1)); // 4

It‚Äôs like lego games; by having a set of pure functions you can easily build your own galaxy.

Why aren‚Äôt pure functions used all the time?
Pure functions are awesome but the real life programs have a bunch of side-effects. Getting a response from the server, reading from the file, printing to the screen ‚àí all these operations have side-effects. You can‚Äôt build a truly useful program just on top of pure functions ‚àí you need functions with side-effects as well.

Don Stewart‚Äôs talk

Haskell has a smart way to distinguish between pure and impure functions. It is common in the Haskell community to write function types for the functions.

makeApple :: Seed ‚Üí IO Apple
makeJuice :: Apple ‚Üí Juice

If you see IO (it‚Äôs a Monad) somewhere in type signature, it means the function is impure.
As well, Haskell has strong static typing. Before running a program, compiler should correctly type check a program (and compiler can catch a dozens of errors!).
Now, let me highlight some parts from Don Stewart‚Äôs talk. Don Stewart leads the Haskell teams in the financial sector. In his talk, he shared how to control complexity of applications with more than 3 million lines of code.

Here are a few tips from him:

‚Ä¢ Types help to control complexity.

‚Ä¢ Compare 2 pricing functions:

f :: Double ‚Üí Double ‚Üí String ‚Üí Double
g :: Rate Libor ‚Üí Spot SGD ‚Üí Date ‚Üí Rate SIBOR

g has more expressive types. In other words, you can say more about the function by looking in function type assuming you know financial domain.

‚Ä¢ Remove unclear types.

‚Ä¢ No side effects. Instead, try to write pure functions as many as possible.

‚Ä¢ Make things simpler by controlling IO and new types.

‚Ä¢ Types are for keeping code maintainable and self-documented.

‚Ä¢ Use ‚Äúnew types‚Äù and ‚Äúdata‚Äù to distinguish unique entities in the system.

‚Ä¢ Using Phantom types, you can tag the things. Make it impossible to mix up or combine values in nonsense ways.

‚Ä¢ As opposed to Stings and Double types have too many valid values for most use cases, Bool often has too little information.
Instead of authenticate :: String -> String -> Bool
write authenticate :: Privileges p => User -> Password -> IO (AuthUser p)

‚Ä¢ Lift errors into types (using Maybe and Either) for¬† making functions modular.

‚Ä¢ Move partial functions to the edges and write total functions as a core of program.

‚Ä¢ Types ‚àí in order to minimize complexity; it helps to deliver faster. Reuse is extremely cheap.

Of course, for the reader unfamiliar with Haskell, these tips don‚Äôt tell much, but let me repeat once more. Basically, the main idea is that you need to use meaningful types as much as possible. In such a way you give a compiler more information about a program and consequently, the compiler helps to catch a lot of errors and hopefully optimize the code. Other simple ideas are to use total functions, move side-effects to the edges of a program. That‚Äôs it!

Haskell to industry

Even if Haskell has a great community with a lot of academic folks behind it, the community is really small compare to the Python or Javascript, or Php communities. It tends to lack some useful libraries, so if you switch to Haskell you should expect to have to contribute a lot to existing libraries or write more libraries for your needs. However, I believe it should be changed soon since a lot of people have realized that the OOP paradigm is not an answer to robust software development, especially in the time when parallel and concurrent programming plays more important role. I understand that re-writing back-end systems on Haskell, if you were building the systems during last 10 years using Javasript, Php, Java may not be an option. As a first step towards Haskell I suggest a ‚ÄúHaskell-like‚Äù language ‚àí Elm. Why Elm? Elm looks a bit simpler to start and it‚Äôs web-browser-based, and so it looks like a good alternative to almighty Javascipt. One more advantage of Elm is that you can introduce it gradually into an existing JS project2. Once you are happy with your front-end using Elm you may think to move some of your back-end services to Haskell. After Elm it should be much easier to start.

Happy hacking!

At the end of this post I‚Äôd like to share a photo with one of the core Haskell developers, Simon Peyton Jones.
